{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3349928,"name":"Joseph Farkas","username":"MrRedness","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrredness/{size}/229088_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-02T04:59:21.147Z","cooked":"

Been battling a rare but persistent bug that shows up once every couple hours of driver practice (and also in 1 match at competition). The issue always seemingly occurs right around scheduling/cancelling commands dealing with our intake subsystem (although I haven’t been able to prove its origin). I can share that code if it helps. The closest I found to others encountering this issue was some commentary on a WPILIB PR last summer that mentioned wacky behavior when scheduling another command at the end of a command, which IS something we do, so if that’s undefined behavior we can try something else.

Hoping to see if anyone has thoughts: any ideas welcome and thanks!

Hey, C++ team here. Definitely going to need to see some code to even have an idea about what might be problematic.

My instinct is that commands scheduling commands is weird and generally should be handled by a command composition technique, but it’s totally possible you have a niche use-case.

I also hate to be that guy that says “it breaks when we do X” “well then don’t do X!”, and I’d be very curious to dig into the underlying issue.

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

C++ Command Based: Assertion failed: isHandleInSync() && “invalid iterator access!”

opened 05:17AM - 02 Apr 24 UTC
MrRedness

Been battling a rare but persistent bug that shows up once every couple hours of… driver practice (and also in 1 match at competition). The issue always seemingly occurs right around scheduling/cancelling commands dealing with our intake subsystem (although I haven’t been able to prove its origin). I can share that code if it helps. The closest I found to others encountering this issue was some commentary on a [PR last summer](https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/5470#issuecomment-1659500434) that mentioned wacky behavior when scheduling another command at the end of a command, which IS something we do, so if that’s undefined behavior we can try something else. Hoping to see if anyone has thoughts: any ideas welcome and thanks!

I explained some more here along with our efforts to resolve it. There’s also a .zip link to our code.

Would you by any chance have the full error message?

Usually assertion failures will include a line number, I just wanted to see what line in WPILib checked the assertion to see what exactly the conditions for triggering it are.

EDIT: Nevermind, I found the offending line.

I posted some theories on the github issue.

I’d have to echo their advice and restructure to not schedule commands within a command, unfortunately.
